We can conclude no implications for practice at this stage. The effectiveness and value of interventions for improving the quality of life of people with HIV are unclear.

There is evidence that exercise can be used as a tool to reduce weight. Most of the studies were done in the 1970s and 1980s and re-evaluation of the strategy and effectiveness of the intervention in the era of antenatal steroid use and early use of exercise-related drugs is indicated. There is no evidence that exercise can be used as a tool to reduce weight.

There is some indication that aromatherapy may be a useful intervention for pain management during labour. This conclusion is limited by small study sizes and lack of standardisation in the choice of outcome measures.
There is evidence that dietary changes can reduce blood pressure in people with hypertension. This finding is limited by small study sizes and lack of standardisation in the choice of intervention.

There is evidence that social media campaigns can increase exposure to HIV testing information, increase knowledge about syphilis, increase exposure to pornography and reduce risky sexual practices. However, there is insufficient evidence that these campaigns can reduce syphilis infections. We recommend that social media campaigns providing information about HIV testing be more carefully designed and that campaigns providing more information about testing are more carefully designed.

There is evidence that knowledge brokering is effective in increasing the use of research evidence in the formulation of public health policies and programs. However, there is no evidence that the use of knowledge brokering is effective in increasing the use of research evidence in the formulation of public health policies and programs. The effectiveness of knowledge brokering may be improved with the development of a more robust online registry of research evidence.

Autologous haemopoietic stem cells (BEAM) are effective in treating patients with Hodgkin's disease but are associated with more adverse effects and do not improve the prognosis of patients with relapsed HL. In the absence of evidence from randomized controlled trials, patients with Hodgkin's disease are advised to continue with standard chemotherapy until further evidence is available. However, in the absence of evidence from randomised controlled trials, patients should be offered entry into a clinical trial.

Interventions to reduce the risk of intimate partner violence being repeated are growing. One of the most effective interventions was a screening program for women at risk for intimate partner violence. It resulted in a 10% reduction in the frequency of episodes of intimate partner violence, which was small compared to other interventions. Another significant result was a 10% reduction in the frequency of postpartum violence. This intervention was not statistically significant compared to other interventions.

There is evidence that certain drugs can prolong survival in patients with advanced colonic cancer. One such drug is allopurinol. This drug appears to be effective in preventing the free radicals that cause cancer. However, there is no evidence that this drug can reduce mortality. There is no evidence that this drug can reduce the risk of all-cause mortality.

There is some indication that exercise may be beneficial for children with asthma. Most of the available studies are not of high methodological quality and further research is needed.

The use of a guidewire-guided cannulation technique for the cannulation of the common bile duct is associated with a lower rate of post-ERCP pancreatitis and may reduce the risk of all-cause mortality. However, the results of studies regarding the usefulness of WGC are conflicting. A single-center, blinded trial of conventional cannulation technique using sphinctertome and contrast injection versus guidewire cannulation technique is needed to determine whether this reduces the rate of post-ERCP pancreatitis.

Early endoscopic intervention, especially in the early stages of pancreatitis, is possible to reduce the risk of all-cause mortality and hospital stay in patients with acute pancreatitis who are undergoing EI. This update of the review does not contain any new trials published in full.

Teriflunomide appears to be a safe and effective add-on therapy to interferon-β in patients with RRMS. Its effects on disease activity and relapse rate are consistent with previous evidence. A transdermal patch has been tested in one trial, and there is evidence that the lower dose smaller patch is associated with fewer side effects than the higher dose larger patch and has comparable efficacy to both. This review has not examined economic data.

There is evidence that progressive use of interventions to increase contraceptive uptake and contraceptive use among women in HIV-1-serodiscordant partnerships are effective in reducing the incidence of pregnancy and in decreasing the risk of HIV infection. progressive use of interventions to increase contraceptive uptake and in decreasing the risk of HIV infection and in decreasing the risk of pregnancy are effective in reducing the incidence of both HIV and contraception.

We can conclude no implications for practice at this stage. tinzaparin appears to be effective in reducing painful crisis of sickle cell anemia. In patients with acute painful crisis of SCA, tinzaparin appears to be effective in reducing the duration of painful crisis and in reducing the incidence of bleeding. This update of the review provides additional data to support the current evidence.

Tranexamic acid may be useful for reducing erythrocyte transfusion in patients undergoing hip fracture surgery. However, there is insufficient evidence from this study's safety data and further research is required. This treatment may be more effective than saline at reducing erythrocyte transfusion but may be more harmful than tranexamic acid in increasing the risk of vascular events. Further trials are needed to determine if the benefits of tranexamic acid are truly substantial and if so, at what dose and in which clinical setting.

There is evidence that peritoneal closure is effective in reducing pain and in reducing the risk of hernia after abdominal surgery. However, there is no evidence that it is effective in reducing the risk of abdominal pain and in reducing the risk of hernia after abdominal surgery. This review underlines the urgent need to conduct randomized controlled trials on the incision used in abdominal surgery.

There is no convincing evidence to support the use of antiepileptic drugs for the prophylactic treatment of migraine. The current evidence base is limited due to the differing methodologies employed in the trials and inconsistencies in reporting of outcomes. Further evidence from good-quality, contemporary trials is required in order to assess the effectiveness and safety of gabapentin in the prophylaxis of migraine.
